title: [whatwg-streams] Fixes and improvements
body:
Fixes various issues where the type definitions did not match the spec:
* `TransformStreamTransformer` and `TransformStreamDefaultController` had `R` and `W` type parameters the wrong way around. The transformer receives chunks written to the writable end (`W`), transforms them and then enqueues them to the readable end (`R`).
* `pipeTo` must pipe to a compatible `WritableStream` (that accepts chunks of type `R`)
* `cancel()` and `abort()` accept `any` reason
* `enqueue()` returns `void` (instead of `number`)
* Controllers and BYOB request classes are not constructable, so remove constructors
* `ReadableStreamBYOBReader.read` and `ReadableStreamBYOBRequest.respondWithNewView` accept any `ArrayBufferView`. It doesn't need to match the stream's chunk type.
* `desiredSize` can be `null` when stream is errored
* `WritableStreamSink.write` can return `void` or a promise
* Allow promise with any result from source/sink/transformer methods (although the actual result will be ignored)
* Use `export interface` instead of `declare interface` for `TransformStreamTransformer` (for consistency)
* Use `readonly` properties where applicable
* Fix indentation (for consistency)

Updated tests with new/updated spec examples:
* Update example 8.9 with extra `TextEncoderStream` step.
* Add usage snippet from example 8.9
* Add example 8.10 (sync mapper)

---

title: node: make streams generic
body:
## Motivation

1. Given the fact that `Readable` stream [became](https://github.com/nodejs/node/commit/61b4d60c5d) `AsyncIterable` in Node v10.0.0, I expect `for-await-of` way of iterating over streams to become more popular. As a result people may start using native streams more often. And probably they will be using the streams with their own data types (i.e. in object mode), so it will be great to check these data types.
2. There is no type support for streams in object mode. The only type streams operate is `string | Buffer` or `any`

## Use case

My use case is iterating over documents returned by MongoDB. So I could write

```ts
const docs = db.collection<MyDataType>('...').find();
// docs is Cursor<MyDataType>, which extends Readable stream
for await (const doc of docs) {
  // I expect doc to be MyDataType here, but it is string | Buffer at the moment
}
```
---

body:
According to the official documentation

> Like other classes in D3, layouts follow the method chaining pattern where setter methods return the layout itself, allowing multiple setters to be invoked in a concise statement.

And d3.layout.treemap.sticky specifically https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Treemap-Layout.md#sticky  should return Treemap<T>.

This file should comply with the actual API, why it is not?

title: [jquery] Fix compatibility issue with `@types/bluebird-global`.
body:
`@types/jquery` used the global Promise interface to indicate compatibility with other Promise implementations. `@types/bluebird-global` modifies the global Promise interface making it unsafe to use.

To remedy this, a private copy of the global Promise interface is introduced.

Fixes #26328

Disabled `no-redundant-jsdoc-2` as I'm not sure what the alternative is supposed to be.

Closes #26503

title: [@types/decompress] decompress function should have four overloads
body:
kevaa/decompress exports a function with 4 overloads:

1. decompress (input, output, opts)
2. decompress (input, output)
3. decompress (input, opts)
4. decompress (input)

Prior definition did not support third and fourth overload patterns. This pull request corrects that.

title: :bug: PouchDB-find: return ExistingDocument instead of Document
body:
`find` returns `ExistingDocument`s, including the `_rev`, not just `Document`s that don't include it.

Without it, TypeScript complains when trying to update a doc that was got via `find` because it "doesn't have a `_rev` field". While actually it does.

title: [jsdom] [parse5] - fix @types/jsdom import errors
body:
Please fill in this template.

- [x] Use a meaningful title for the pull request. Include the name of the package modified.
- [x] Test the change in your own code. (Compile and run.)
- [x] Add or edit tests to reflect the change. (Run with `npm test`.)
- [x] Follow the advice from the [readme](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/README.md#make-a-pull-request).
- [x] Avoid [common mistakes](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/README.md#common-mistakes).
- [x] Run `npm run lint package-name` (or `tsc` if no `tslint.json` is present).

---

This change adds `v4` of the parse5 types. The types are copy/paste from [here](https://github.com/inikulin/parse5/commit/3bfa7d9f3297f96772a8eb26d9cfc4d79314af8b#diff-0e3ac3694919aca1db302bc3ebe669f2) which is a link to the commit where the types were removed for parse5@5

I copied and modified the unit tests from parse5@5 for the parse5@4 unit tests. These probably aren't as complete as they could be, but I'm not overly familiar with parse5 so wasn't able to write idiomatic tests.

---

The motivation here is actually that `@types/jsdom@11.0.5` is broken (failed import) because it is now pulling in the incompatible `@types/parse5@5` where previously it was pulling the types from `parse5@3`. From [here](https://github.com/jsdom/jsdom/blob/master/package.json#L34) I see that jsdom uses `parse5@4` hence my decision to move those types and bump the `@types/jsdom` dependency on parse5.

I have never added a major version subfolder for a DT package before, so extra eyes to make sure I did that correctly would be much appreciated!

This should fix #26338

It is clearly allowed by the runtime and affects layout.

title: [jquery] Fix documentation links for Visual Studio Code.
body:
Visual Studio Code does not handle `@link` tags. It ends up creating a link which includes the closing `}` which does not represent the correct documentation link. This PR inserts a space after the link to prevent the `}` from being appended. It also surrounds `@link` tags with backticks to prevent Visual Studio code from splitting it up into 3 lines.

Fixes #25235

#### WebStorm 2018.1.4

##### Before
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5265970/41508324-e8c1a2fa-7210-11e8-819f-9a4b318ba647.png)

##### After
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5265970/41249004-bf1d4c72-6d80-11e8-94ce-8d4a0eb49dee.png)

#### Visual Studio Code 1.24.0

##### Before
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5265970/41508335-1e618d76-7211-11e8-825d-3124bd59dcae.png)

##### After
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5265970/41249055-e6e54cc8-6d80-11e8-808c-2b4a1ba08d78.png)

---

Closes #26503

A [common use](https://github.com/erikras/redux-form/issues/523) for this capability is to store an array of strings for each field instead. This PR lets the user parameterize SubmissionError and the library's various error properties with whatever type they're using to encode field-level errors. This also fixes FormErrors, so that the object type includes the _error
key at the top-level, not as a nested-object. See docs for that [here](https://redux-form.com/7.3.0/docs/api/submissionerror.md/).
